question.p: A study of young children found that those with more body fat tended to have more "controlling" mothers; the San Francisco Chronicle concluded that "Parents of Fat Kids Should Lighten Up."

ol.li:
Was this an observational study or a randomized controlled experiment?
observational study randomized controlled experiment

Did the study find an association between mother's behavior and her child's level of body fat?
yes no

Suppose controlling behavior by the mother causes children to eat more. Would this fact alone explain an association between controlling behavior by the mother and her child's level of body fat?
yes no

Suppose there is a gene which causes obesity. Would this fact alone explain an association between controlling behavior by the mother and her child's level of body fat?
yes no

In a study to test the Chronicle's conclusion, what would be the treatment and control groups?
overweight and normal weight children controlling and normal parents

Do the data provide strong support for the Chronicle's conclusion?
yes no

hw.question:
A scientist is studying the affect of temperature on a certain species of bacteria. To do so, he measures the metabolic rate of different bacteria colonies from this species 20 times over a wide range of different temperatures that he sets in his lab. He then computes the correlation of metabolic rate and temperature for this species and is surprised to find a very small correlation of -0.04, very close to 0. He concludes that temperature has essentially no effect on metabolism for this species. Do you agree with his analysis?
Sample Correct Solution
Not necessarily. It's possible to imagine his species of bacteria having an optimum temperature at which its metabolic rate is highest, so that if you make the species too hot or too cold, its metabolism decreases. The plot of metabolism versus temperature would then look roughly like an upside-down U. The correlation cannot capture this nonlinear association, so the correlation would be close to 0, even though temperature has a strong effect on metabolism. A scatterplot, on the other hand, would easily reveal the pattern.
Grading Rubric
Please grade this question out of 6 points following these guidelines.
3 points for realizing that the correlation statistic does not fully describe associations between variables
3 points for suggesting a way that the scientist might have observed a low correlation despite a relatively strong causal relationship
Feel free to give partial credit or to use your good judgement if you think the case merits it

question.p: People who get lots of vitamins by eating five or more servings of fresh fruit and vegetables each day (especially "cruciferous" vegetables like broccoli) have much lower death rates from colon cancer and lung cancer, according to many observational studies. These studies were so encouraging that two randomized controlled experiments were done. The treatment groups were given large doses of vitamins supplements, while people in the control groups just ate their usual diet. One experiment looked at colon cancer; the other, at lung cancer.

The first experiment found no difference in the death rate from colon cancer between the treatment group and the control group. The second experiment found that beta carotene (as a diet supplement) increased the death rate from lung cancer. True of false, and explain:

ol.li:
The experiments confirmed the results of the observational studies.
True False

The observational studies could easily have reached the wrong conclusions, due to confounding -- people who eat lots of fruit and vegetables have lifestyles that are different in many other ways too.
True False

The experiments could easily have reached the wrong conclusion, due to confounding -- people who eat lots of fruit and vegetables have lifestyles that are different in many other ways too.
True False

question.p: A study is carried out to determine the effect of party affiliation on voting behavior in a certain city. The city is divided up into two wards. In each ward, the percentage of registered Democrats who vote is higher than the percentage of registered Republicans who vote. True or false: For the city as a whole, the percentage of registered Democrats who vote must be higher than the percentage of registered Republicans who vote. If true, please explain why, and if false, please give a counterexample.

solution.p: False: This is exactly Simpson's Paradox. For example, in Ward A 1000 out of 10000 registered Republicans might vote, and 2000 out of 10000 registered Democrats. In Ward B, 22000 out of 50000 Republicans might vote, and 5000 out of 10000 registered Democrats might vote.

Then in Ward A, 10% of Republicans vote and 20% of Democrats vote. In Ward B, 44% of Republicans vote and 50% of Democrats vote. But in total, (1000 + 22000) / (10000 + 50000) = 38.3% of Republicans vote, but only (2000 + 5000) / (10000 + 10000) = 35% of Democrats vote.
Please grade this question out of 6 points following these guidelines.

ul.li: 2 points for getting the conclusion right
4 points for giving an explicit example of how such a situation might occur.
Feel free to give partial credit or to use your good judgement if you think the case merits it

question.p: A number is missing in each of the data sets below. If possible, fill in the blank to make $r = 1$. If this is not possible, type in "x" into the blank.

Breast cancer is one of the most common malignancies among women in Canada and the U.S. If it is detected early enough -- before the cancer spreads -- chances of successful treatment are much better. Do screening programs speed up detection by enough to matter? Many studies have examined this question.

The Canadian National Breast Cancer Study was a randomized controlled experiment on mammography, that is, x-ray screening for breast cancer. The study found no benefit from screening. (The benefit was measured by comparing death rates from breast cancer in the treatment and control groups.)
Dr. Daniel Kopans argued that the randomization was not done properly: instead of following instructions, nurses assigned high risk women to the treatment group.

ol.li: Would this bias the study? If so, would the bias make the benefit from screening look bigger or smaller than it really is? Explain your answer.
What one change to the study could have ensured a proper randomization?

solution.p: Moving high-risk women from the control group to the treatment group lowers the death rate in the control group and increases the death rate in the treatment group. That biases the study against screening.
To ensure proper randomization, the nurses should have been blinded to the risk status of the patients.
This question is worth 6 points, according to the following guidelines.

ul.li: 2 points for realizing that moving high-risk women from control to treatment biases the study against the treatment.
2 points for realizing that this makes the benefit from screening smaller than it really is.

2 points for arguing that the nurses should have been blinded to the risk status of the patients. (It is important to refer to the term blind specifically.) Accept other answers that are convincingly argued.

solution.p: Partial credit is awarded as appropriate.

question.p: A teaching assistant gives a quiz with 10 questions and no part credit. After grading the papers, the TA writes down for each student the number of questions the student got right and the number wrong. The average number of right answers is 6.4 with an SD of 2.0; the average number of wrong answers is 3.6 with an SD of 2.0. The correlation between the number of right answers and the number of wrong answers is:

An investigator measuring various characteristics of a large group of athletes found that the correlation between the weight of an athlete and the amount of weight that athlete could lift was 0.60. Determine whether each of the following interpretations of the correlation is true or false:

ol.li:
On the average, an athlete can lift 60% of his body weight.
True False

If an athlete gains 10 pounds, he can expect to lift an additional 6 pounds.
True False

60% of an athlete's lifting ability can be attributed to his weight alone.
True False

The more an athlete weighs, on the average the more he can lift.
True False

The more an athlete can lift, on the average the more he weighs.
True False

The positive correlation suggests that an athlete who wants to lift more should try to gain weight.
True False
